misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the problem requirements
misconceptions.description: Instead of implementing a number guessing game with randomness, looping guesses, and feedback ("Too high" / "Too low"), the student implemented a completely different program that calculates the cost of a road trip. This suggests that they may not be carefully translating the assignment text into the required program behavior.
misconceptions.student_belief: I believe the task is to write a program that computes the cost of driving a given distance using miles per gallon and price per gallon.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task is to write an interactive number guessing game: the computer randomly chooses a number between 1 and 100, the user guesses repeatedly, and after each incorrect guess the program reports whether the guess is too high or too low until the correct guess is made.
symptoms: Program prompts for driving distance, miles per gallon, and price per gallon instead of a number guess.
No use of Random or generation of a secret number.
No loop to allow multiple guesses.
No "Too high" or "Too low" output.
Program output is a cost value rather than a game result.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion about the assignment text or reuse of code from a different exercise without adapting it to the current problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Before coding, restate the problem in your own words and outline the required inputs, outputs, and behavior. Double-check that your variable names, prompts, and logic directly correspond to the problem statement. For this question, focus on random number generation, looping for repeated guesses, and conditional feedback messages.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program structure and all prompts correspond to a different standard exercise (road trip cost), with no elements of a number guessing game, indicating a clear mismatch with the assignment.

evidence.note: All prompts and calculations relate to driving cost; there is no random number, guessing logic, or game-related output, showing the program is for a different problem than the assigned number guessing game.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Program Implementation (Solved a different problem)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate the cost of a road trip based on distance, MPG, and fuel price, instead of solving the required Number Guessing Game. This demonstrates a complete misunderstanding or failure to attempt the assigned problem setup.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes they should implement a 'Road Trip Cost' calculator, possibly confusing this assignment with another task or template.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The requirement was to write a 'Number Guessing Game' using random number generation, loops, and conditional logic.
symptoms: Code implements an entirely different calculation task (Road Trip Cost).
Does not include any random number generation, looping, or guessing logic.
Class name does not match the assignment purpose.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misreading the assignment prompt and implementing code for a different, unrequested problem (Road Trip Cost calculation).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please refer back to the prompt for Q2, 'Number Guessing Game', and implement the necessary logic (Random number generation, continuous input loop, and conditional hints).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code solves an entirely different problem ('Road Trip Cost' calculation) and does not align with any requirement of the assigned 'Number Guessing Game'.

evidence.note: The class name suggests the student is working on a different problem.
The inputs requested are for a road trip cost calculation, not a number guess.
The core calculation is for cost, completely irrelevant to the guessing game.

misconceptions.name: Completely Wrong Program Submitted
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a program that solves an entirely different problem (calculating road trip cost) instead of implementing the number guessing game as specified in the assignment.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have either submitted the wrong file or misunderstood the assignment requirements entirely, implementing a road trip cost calculator instead of a guessing game.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires a number guessing game where: (1) the computer generates a random number 1-100, (2) the user enters guesses in a loop, (3) the program provides 'Too high' or 'Too low' hints, and (4) the game ends when the correct number is guessed.
symptoms: No Random number generation present
No loop for repeated guessing
No conditional logic for 'Too high' or 'Too low' hints
Program asks for distance, mpg, and price instead of accepting number guesses
Program terminates after a single calculation instead of looping until correct guess
misconceptions.root_cause: Fundamental misunderstanding or misalignment with the assignment specification. The student either worked on the wrong problem, submitted the wrong file, or did not read the assignment requirements carefully.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start over with the correct problem: Create a program that (1) uses Random to generate a secret number, (2) uses a loop to repeatedly ask for guesses, (3) compares each guess to the secret number and provides hints, and (4) counts the number of guesses before terminating.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the submitted code solves a completely different problem with no elements of the guessing game specification present.

evidence.note: The entire program solves a road trip cost problem, not the number guessing game. No random number generation, no loop for guessing, no comparison logic, no game termination condition.

misconceptions.name: Implemented a completely different program than the required number guessing game
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a road trip cost calculator instead of a number guessing game where the computer picks a random number between 1 and 100 and the user guesses until correct with 'Too high'/'Too low' feedback. This indicates a misinterpretation of the problem requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: I need to write a program that asks for driving distance, miles per gallon, and price per gallon, then computes and prints the cost of driving.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should implement a number guessing game: generate a random secret number between 1 and 100, repeatedly prompt the user to guess, print 'Too high' or 'Too low' after incorrect guesses, and stop only when the user guesses correctly, then report how many guesses were taken.
symptoms: Program prompts for driving distance, miles per gallon, and fuel price instead of guesses between 1 and 100.
No use of Random or random number generation.
No loop that allows multiple guesses.
No conditional logic for 'Too high' or 'Too low' hints.
No termination condition based on a correct guess.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different assignment problems or not carefully reading the specific requirements for the number guessing game.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the full problem statement and list the exact required behaviors (inputs, outputs, and control flow) before starting to code. Then design a solution that directly matches those requirements, including random number generation, a guess loop, and high/low feedback.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire submission is focused on a road trip cost calculation and contains none of the constructs or behaviors required for a number guessing game.

evidence.note: This code calculates the cost of a road trip using distance, mpg, and fuel price; it does not implement any part of the required number guessing game (no random number, no guessing loop, no 'Too high'/'Too low' feedback).

misconceptions.name: Misunderstanding of Assignment Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a solution to a completely different problem (Road Trip Cost Calculator) instead of the Number Guessing Game. This indicates a fundamental misunderstanding or misreading of the assignment specifications.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the assignment was asking them to create a road trip cost calculator program.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment specifically requires a number guessing game where: (1) the computer generates a random number 1-100, (2) the user enters guesses in a loop, (3) the program provides 'Too high' or 'Too low' feedback, and (4) the game ends when the guess is correct with a count of attempts.
symptoms: No random number generation using Random class
No loop structure for repeated guessing
No comparison logic for high/low feedback
No termination condition based on correct guess
Program solves an entirely different problem
misconceptions.root_cause: Student may have submitted the wrong file, misread the assignment, or confused this assignment with a different one.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the assignment requirements carefully. Start fresh with: (1) import Random class, (2) generate answer = rand.nextInt(100) + 1, (3) create a while/do-while loop, (4) read user guesses, (5) compare and provide feedback, (6) count guesses, (7) exit when guess == answer.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is absolute certainty (100% confidence) that this is the wrong program. The assignment requirements are explicitly stated, and this submission addresses none of them.

evidence.note: Entire program is a road trip cost calculator with no elements of a guessing game (no Random, no loop for guesses, no comparison for high/low feedback, no termination on correct guess)
